Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I was texting my stepdad, checking in like I always do—“Everything okay at home?”—when the crowd around me started to shift. The police had begun blocking the exits, their presence suddenly more than just a backdrop to our protest. My phone buzzed with his reply, a simple, “We’re fine, but your mom’s been quiet lately. Can we talk tonight?” I felt the weight of his words, the unspoken request for me to be present, to listen, to be the glue holding our patchwork family together. But right now, my activist group needed me. People were looking to me for direction, waiting for me to help coordinate a safe exit, to keep everyone calm and organized. My heart pounded as I tried to split my attention—one hand on my phone, the other waving to get my friends’ attention. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, my family’s need for reassurance and my responsibility to the people here, both urgent, both impossible to ignore.
